==Japanese==

===Kanji===
{{ja-kanji|grade=n|rs=木07}}

# a [[tub]], a [[bucket]]

====Readings====
{{ja-readings
|goon=[[つう]] (tsū)
|kanon=[[とう]] (tō)
|kanyoon=[[よう]] (yō)
|kun=[[おけ]] (oke), [[こが]] (koga)
|nanori=[[おけ]] (oke), [[あきら]] (akira), [[おけざき]] (okezaki), [[とうず]] (tōzu)
}}

===Etymology 1===
<div style="float:right;">
{{wikipedia|lang=ja}}
[[File:Oke_neko.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|桶}} (''oke''): A small '''''oke''''' holding a cat.]]
[[File:Fujimi_Fuji_view_field_in_the_Owari_province.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|桶}} (''oke''): A workman building a large '''''oke'''''.]]
</div>
{{ja-kanjitab|おけ|yomi=kun}}
From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=おけ}}. Originally a compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=おけ|麻|tr1=o|t1=flax, ramie|笥|tr2=ke|t2=a container, especially for foodstuffs or tableware}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

====Pronunciation====
* {{l|ja|sc=Latn|訓読み|Kun'yomi}}
* {{ja-accent-common|a|お|け}}<ref>{{R:NHK Hatsuon}}</ref>
* {{IPA|lang=ja|[o̞ke̞]}}

====Alternative forms====
* {{ja-l|麻笥}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|おけ|hhira=をけ}}

# A tube-shaped container for holding split [[flax]] or [[hemp]], usually made of thin [[cypress]] wood bent to shape.
# By extension, a [[pail]], [[bucket]], [[tub]], or [[basin]] similar to a [[barrel]] in construction, made of long thin pieces of [[cedar]] or cypress extending up from a base and held in place with [[hoop]]s. Can be small enough to carry in one hand, or large enough to bathe in.
# {{lb|ja|sort=おけ|Noh theater}} A stool on stage, on which an actor sits.

=====Synonyms=====
* {{sense|bucket}} {{ja-l|バケツ||baketsu}}
* {{sense|stool}} {{ja-l|床几|しょうぎ|shōgi}}, {{ja-l|鬘桶|かつらおけ|katsura oke}}

=====Idioms=====
{{der-top|Idioms}}
* {{ja-l|桶な物打ち明ける|おけなものうちあける|oke na mono uchiakeru}}, {{ja-l|桶の物打ち明ける|おけのものうちあける|oke no mono uchiakeru}}: "open up what's in your bucket" → to [[come clean]] to someone, with [[no hard feelings]] and no [[subterfuge]]
* {{ja-l|桶が腐れば菜が腐る|おけがくさればながくさる|oke ga kusareba na ga kusaru}}: "if the bucket rots, the greens rot" → if the surrounding is bad, it affects the inside
{{der-bottom}}

=====Derived terms=====
{{der-top}}
* {{ja-l|桶越し|おけごし|okegoshi}}: using an ''oke'' to cross a river
* {{ja-l|桶屋|おけや|okeya}}: a person or store that makes, fixes, and/or sells ''oke'' and well walls
* {{ja-l|桶火|おけび|okebi}}: the fire in a ''hioke''
* {{ja-l|火桶|ひおけ|hioke}}: a type of wooden [[hibachi]]
* {{ja-l|桶狭間|おけはざま|Okehazama}}: a place in the south of Midori-ku, Nagoya
* {{ja-l|桶狭間焼き|おけはざまやき|Okehazama-yaki}}: a style of [[pottery]] originating near Okehazama
* {{ja-l|桶結い|おけゆい|okeyui}}: tying cord bands around an ''oke''; an ''oke'' maker, an ''okeya''
* {{ja-l|桶絞り|おけしぼり|okeshibori}}: a cloth [[dying]] process whereby the sections to leave undyed are put into ''oke'' and closed in with lids
* {{ja-l|桶酸い|おけすい|okesui}}: alternate name for {{ja-l|酢の木}}, {{ja-l|酢木|すのき|sunoki}}: {{taxlink|Vaccinium smallii|species|noshow=1}}, var. ''glabrum'', a bush with edible (though sour) berries
* {{ja-l|桶取り|おけとり|oketori}}: a scene in a ''[[狂言#Japanese|kyōgen]]'' farce presented between Noh plays; a woman working as a water carrier
* {{ja-l|桶尻|おけじり|okejiri}}: the [[aft]] edge of the [[hull]] of a ship in traditional Japanese [[shipbuilding]]
* {{ja-l|桶据え|おけすえ|okesue}}: the [[hipbone]]
* {{ja-l|桶川|おけがわ|Okegawa}}: a river in southeast Saitama Prefecture
* {{ja-l|桶側|おけがわ|okegawa}}: the sides of an ''oke'', the [[stave]]s; a bowl-shaped container for holding trawling lines on a fishing boat
* {{ja-l|桶側胴|おけがわどう|okegawa dō}}: a type of [[breastplate]] made of steel strips bound together, somewhat similar to how ''okegawa'' are bound together to make an ''oke''
* {{ja-l|桶大工|おけだいく|oke daiku}}: a [[cooper]], a [[woodworker]] who specializes in making [[barrel]]s, ''oke'', and well walls
* {{ja-l|桶胴|おけどう|oke dō}}: alternate name for {{ja-l|桶側胴|tr=''okegawa dō''}}; a type of ''[[taiko]]'' drum
* {{ja-l|桶風呂|おけぶろ|okeburo}}: an ''oke'' fitted with a [[firebox]] for heating bathwater: a traditional Japanese wooden ''ofuro'' hottub
* {{ja-l|桶伏せ|おけぶせ|okebuse}}: wearing an ''oke'' on one's head: a mob punishment in the pleasure districts of early Edo-period Japan, where non-paying customers would be forced to wear an ''oke'' on their heads, were sat down on the side of the street, and forced to pay up
{{der-bottom}}
